questions.questionLabel: What is a component in Angular?
Explain the purpose of the NgModule in Angular.
How do you create a new Angular application?
What is data binding in Angular, and what are the different types of data binding?
Explain the difference between {{}} (interpolation) and [property] (property binding) in Angular templates.
What is the difference between let, const, and var in JavaScript?
Explain the concept of closures in JavaScript.
What is the difference between == and === in JavaScript?
What are arrow functions in JavaScript and how do they differ from regular functions?
Explain the concept of promises and async/await in JavaScript.
What is the Document Object Model (DOM) in HTML?
What is the difference between div and span elements in HTML?
Explain the purpose of semantic HTML elements.
What is the difference between block-level and inline elements in HTML?
What are HTML5 form elements and their attributes?
What is the CSS Box Model?
What is the difference between margin and padding in CSS?
Explain the difference between flexbox and grid in CSS.
What is CSS specificity and how does it work?
What are CSS pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements?

answers.answerLabel: A reusable building block for the user interface
A style in Angular
A service for handling HTTP requests
A routing configuration
NgModule is used to declare and configure modules in Angular applications.
NgModule is a component in Angular.
NgModule is used for data binding in Angular.
NgModule is a directive in Angular.
You can create a new Angular application using the Angular CLI by running 'ng new app-name'.
You can create a new Angular application by writing HTML and CSS files.
You can create a new Angular application using pure JavaScript.
You can create a new Angular application using Python.
Data binding in Angular is a mechanism for synchronizing data between the component and the view.
Data binding in Angular is used for creating components.
Data binding in Angular is a routing feature.
Data binding in Angular is only available for services.
{{}} (interpolation) is used for displaying dynamic data in the template.
[property] (property binding) is used for displaying dynamic data in the template.
{{}} (interpolation) is used for creating CSS styles.
[property] (property binding) is used for creating services.
let and const are block-scoped, while var is function-scoped. const cannot be reassigned, while let can be.
There is no difference between let, const, and var.
var is block-scoped, while let and const are function-scoped.
All three are exactly the same in JavaScript.
Closures are functions that have access to variables in their outer (enclosing) lexical scope, even after the outer function has returned.
Closures are a way to close a browser tab in JavaScript.
Closures are used only for event handling in JavaScript.
Closures are a type of variable in JavaScript.
== performs type coercion before comparison, while === performs strict comparison without type coercion.
== and === are exactly the same in JavaScript.
=== performs type coercion, while == does not.
== is used for assignment, while === is used for comparison.
Arrow functions are a shorter syntax for writing functions and they don't have their own 'this' binding.
Arrow functions are exactly the same as regular functions in JavaScript.
Arrow functions can only be used in Angular applications.
Arrow functions are deprecated in modern JavaScript.
Promises are objects representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation. async/await is syntactic sugar for working with promises.
Promises and async/await are the same thing in JavaScript.
Promises are only used for HTTP requests, while async/await is for DOM manipulation.
async/await is deprecated and should not be used.
The DOM is a programming interface that represents the structure of HTML documents as a tree of nodes.
The DOM is a CSS framework.
The DOM is a JavaScript library for animations.
The DOM is only used in Angular applications.
div is a block-level element, while span is an inline element.
div and span are exactly the same in HTML.
span is a block-level element, while div is an inline element.
div and span are both deprecated in HTML5.
Semantic HTML elements provide meaning to the content, making it more accessible and SEO-friendly.
Semantic HTML elements are only for styling purposes.
Semantic HTML elements are deprecated in HTML5.
Semantic HTML elements are only used in Angular templates.
Block-level elements take up the full width available and start on a new line, while inline elements only take up as much width as needed.
Block-level and inline elements are the same in HTML.
Block-level elements are inline, and inline elements are block-level.
The distinction between block-level and inline elements was removed in HTML5.
HTML5 form elements include input, textarea, select, button, and various input types like email, date, number, etc., with attributes like required, placeholder, pattern.
HTML5 form elements are the same as HTML4 form elements.
HTML5 form elements are only available in Angular applications.
HTML5 does not support form elements.
The CSS Box Model describes how elements are rendered as boxes with content, padding, border, and margin.
The CSS Box Model is used for creating animations.
The CSS Box Model is only applicable to flexbox layouts.
The CSS Box Model is deprecated in modern CSS.
Margin is the space outside the element's border, while padding is the space inside the element's border, between the border and the content.
Margin and padding are exactly the same in CSS.
Padding is outside the border, while margin is inside the border.
Margin and padding are only available in CSS Grid.
Flexbox is designed for one-dimensional layouts (row or column), while Grid is designed for two-dimensional layouts (rows and columns simultaneously).
Flexbox and Grid are exactly the same in CSS.
Grid is for one-dimensional layouts, while Flexbox is for two-dimensional layouts.
Both Flexbox and Grid are deprecated in modern CSS.
CSS specificity is a set of rules that determines which CSS rule is applied when multiple rules target the same element.
CSS specificity is used for creating animations.
CSS specificity only applies to inline styles.
CSS specificity is deprecated in modern CSS.
Pseudo-classes style elements based on their state (e.g., :hover), while pseudo-elements style specific parts of elements (e.g., ::before).
Pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements are exactly the same in CSS.
Pseudo-elements style elements based on state, while pseudo-classes style specific parts.
Pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements are only available in CSS Grid.
